content.text: C++ Omit Array Size
Omit Array Size
In C++, you don't have to specify the size of the array. The compiler is smart enough to determine the size of the array based on the number of inserted values:
content.html: In C++, you don't have to specify the size of the array. The compiler is smart enough to determine the size of the array based on the number of inserted values:

content.code_html: string cars[] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; // Three array elements

content.text: The example above is equal to:

syntaxHighlighting.text: string cars[3] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; // Also three array elements

content.code: string cars[3] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; // Also three array elements

syntax_highlighting.text: string cars[3] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; // Also three array elements

content.code_html: string cars[3] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; // Also three array elements

syntax_highlighting_data.text: string cars[3] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; // Also three array elements

content.text: However, the last approach is considered as "good practice", because it will reduce the chance of errors in your program.
content.html: However, the last approach is considered as "good practice", because it will reduce the chance of errors in your program.

content.text: Omit Elements on Declaration
It is also possible to declare an array without specifying the elements on declaration, and add them later:
content.html: It is also possible to declare an array without specifying the elements on declaration, and add them later:

content.code_html:
string cars[5];
cars[0] = "Volvo";
cars[1] = "BMW";
cars[2] = "Ford";
cars[3] = "Mazda";
cars[4] = "Tesla";

content.text: Note: The example above only works when you have specified the size of the array.
content.html: Note: The example above only works when you have specified the size of the array.

content.text: If you don't specify the array size, an error occurs:
content.html: If you don't specify the array size, an error occurs:

content.code_html:
string cars[];  // Array size is not specified
cars[0] = "Volvo";
cars[1] = "BMW";
cars[2] = "Ford";
cars[3] = "Mazda";
cars[4] = "Tesla";

// error: array size missing in 'cars'

content.text: Fixed Size (Arrays) vs. Dynamic Size (Vectors)
You will often hear the terms "fixed size" and "dynamic size" when discussing arrays in C++.
content.html: You will often hear the terms "fixed size" and "dynamic size" when discussing arrays in C++.

content.text: This is because the size of an array in C++ is fixed, meaning you cannot add or remove elements after it is created.
content.html: This is because the size of an array in C++ is fixed, meaning you cannot add or remove elements after it is created.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will 
  result in an error

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will 
  result in an error

content.code_html:
// An array with 3 elements
string cars[3] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};

// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will result in an error
cars[3] = "Tesla";

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Trying to add another element (a fourth element) to the cars array will 
  result in an error

content.text: Vectors
For operations that require adding and removing array elements, C++ provides vectors , which are resizable arrays .
content.html: For operations that require adding and removing array elements, C++ provides vectors, which are resizable arrays.

content.text: The size of a vector is dynamic, meaning it can grow and shrink as needed.
content.html: The size of a vector is dynamic, meaning it can grow and shrink as needed.

content.text: Vectors are found in the <vector> library, and they come with many useful functions to add, remove and modify elements:
content.html: Vectors are found in the <vector> library, and they come with many useful functions to add, remove and modify elements:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// A vector with 3 elementsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};
  // Adding another element to the vectorcars.push_back("Tesla");
// Adding another element to the vector

content.code:
// A vector with 3 elementsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};
// Adding another element to the vectorcars.push_back("Tesla");

syntax_highlighting.text:
// A vector with 3 elementsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};
 // Adding another element to the vectorcars.push_back("Tesla");
// Adding another element to the vector

content.code_html:
// A vector with 3 elements
vector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};

// Adding another element to the vector
cars.push_back("Tesla");

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// A vector with 3 elementsvector<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};
  // Adding another element to the vectorcars.push_back("Tesla");
// Adding another element to the vector

content.text: This was just an introduction to vectors to let you know that "resizable arrays" exist.
content.html: This was just an introduction to vectors to let you know that "resizable arrays" exist.

content.text: Don't worry if you don't understand the syntax above.
content.html: Don't worry if you don't understand the syntax above.

content.text: You will learn much more about vectors and other data structures in a later chapter .
content.html: You will learn much more about vectors and other data structures in a later chapter.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What happens if you omit the size of an array when declaring it with initial values?
content.html: What happens if you omit the size of an array when declaring it with initial values?

metadata.question: What happens if you omit the size of an array when declaring it with initial values?

options.text: The compiler determines the array size based on the number of values provided
The array has a size of 0
